newsitem.title: USA: Dollar ends mixed amid talk of official intervention.
newsitem.headline: Dollar ends mixed amid talk of official intervention.

text.p: The dollar ended mixed Thursday as a German official voiced concern over its continuing strength and speculation emerged in London that central bankers had stepped in to sell dollars for yen.
But traders said solid economic growth in the United States, coupled with sharp gains in U.S. stock and bond markets, sustained investors' interest in the dollar.
"The bottom line is, the fundamentals look very good for the dollar," said Hans Boman, chief spot currency dealer at Swedbank in New York.

The dollar slumped after a comment late on Wednesday from Johann Wilhelm Gaddum, a vice president of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, who told Reuters in Bangkok, "It is not in the interest of the Bundesbank that the strength of the dollar goes further and further."
While most long-term investors held their dollars after Gaddum's comments, short-term market players sold the U.S. currency, which fell nearly a pfennig against the German mark.
"The market is nervous. The dollar keeps putting in new highs, but it retreats quickly because of fears of central bank intervention," said Chris Iggo, chief economist at BZW Securities.
The dollar fell to 1.6847 marks late in New York from 1.6892 late on Wednesday, but it rose to 124.40 Japanese yen from 124.25 on Wednesday.
Traders in London reported a rumour that the Bank of England had entered the market to support the yen on behalf of Japanese authorities, which promptly sent the dollar half a yen lower.
Though most observers were sceptical, the market's reaction highlighted its respect for official threats to intervene if the dollar's spirited rally fails to slow.
"The rumour scared people off a little bit. But realistically, I don't think the central banks are going to do anything until the dollar gets to 1.75 marks," Boman said.

A late rally in U.S. financial markets pushed the Dow Jones industrial average above 7,000 for the first time and the benchmark 30-year Treasury up nearly one point, helping provide support for further dollar gains, dealers said.
The Dow rose 60.81 points to 7,022.44, its second straight record high. The 30-year Treasury yield fell to 6.63 percent from 6.71 percent on Wednesday.
The British pound fell against the dollar and other currencies as Kenneth Clarke, Britain's finance minister, told Sky Television the pound's recent rally would reduce British inflation.
Clarke's comments dampened broad-based expectations of an imminent hike in official British interest rates, which had helped push the pound to a four-year high against the mark in recent weeks.
The British pound fell to $1.6240 from $1.6313.
The dollar rose to 1.4552 Swiss francs from 1.4535 but it fell to Canadian $1.3515 from C$1.3555.
U.S. currency markets will close early Friday in observance of the Presidents Day holiday on Monday.
